clues.text: This Nazi was known as the "Angel of Death"; in 1985 his remains were found in a grave in Brazil
Germany's ME-262 jet fighter was made by this manufacturer
The battle for this island in the Ryukyus resulted in 12,500 U.S. deaths, the heaviest toll in the Pacific war
On May 7, 1945 Germany signed the Articles of Surrender in this city, the coronation place of French kings
In terms of tonnage involved, the 1944 battle for this Philippine gulf was the greatest in history
William Shatner's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame is in front of this theater that opened in 1927
Shatner plays Boston attorney Denny Crane on this spinoff of "The Practice"
Shatner had a recurring role on this 1960s TV show named for a doctor
Shatner played Capt. Byers, an aide to Spencer Tracy, in this war crimes trial drama
One of William Shatner's early movie roles was as Alexi in this 1958 film based on a Dostoyevsky novel
The National Earthquake Information Center is in this "colorful" city just west of Denver
This New Mexico city was founded in 1706 & named for a viceroy of New Spain
The growth of this state capital in Eagle Valley was stimulated by the discovery of the Comstock Lode in 1859
This raisin center of more than 400,000 people in California's San Joaquin Valley has grapes on its seal
Montana State University has a branch in this city named for frontiersman John
Longtime Chicago Bear Harold "Red" Grange was also known by this "spectral" nickname
In 1935 this pollster founded the American Institute of Public Opinion
The literary works of this onetime film critic include "This Gun for Hire" & "The Power and the Glory"
Born near Melbourne, this Aussie feminist is best known for her revolutionary work "The Female Eunuch"
Born in France in 1807, he played a leading part in the unification of Italy
Burns never said he wrote this now traditional Scottish song of parting, he rewrote an earlier song
This was Burns' day job, hence the rustic touch to his poetry
The Kilmarnock Volume by Burns includes the famous "To a Louse" & this title that's one letter different
The hornpipes & strathspeys Burns mentions in a poem are these
Hat's off to this Burns poem based on the legend of Alloway Kirk

rounds.comments: (Alex: I will give you a word, and you have to give me the two parts of speech that word might be used as.  For example, if I said "flirt", that would be a noun and a verb.  All right?)

clues.text: Complete
Main
Sting
Dull
Hard
He once said, "I have never given anybody hell.  I just tell the truth... & they think it's hell"
Showing he'd rather switch than fight, this future pres. changed from Democrat to Republican in 1962
At the shooting, his assassin cried, "I am a stalwart & Arthur is president now!"
Shortly after being elected, he submitted his resignation as president of Columbia University
Jefferson Davis was the son-in-law of this president who died in office
In 1988 officials in this country admitted they had printed false maps for years to fool enemies
Hannibal had 38 of these animals when he began crossing the Alps, but few survived the ice & snow
Imported into Brazil from Africa, these "killer" insects escaped the lab & bred with locals
The U.S. Army awarded 8,612 medals after this 1983 invasion although fewer than 7,000 troops were there
Both the father & son of the Frankish leader Charles Martel were named this
Norsemen believed the universe was supported by a huge one of these of the ash variety
Norse legend says a snake coiled around the world & this god of the sky will someday kill each other
Odin rode an eight-legged one of these named Sleipnir
Sigurd, called the most important hero in Norse myth, is famous for killing Fafnir, one of these
Bifrost, the bridge that connected the Earth with the home of the gods, was one of these
Of means, medians & modes, the term that's often called the arithmetic average
Fraction that's equivalent to the infinite decimal .666666...
His theorem is often expressed a² + b² = c²
Its symbol is called a radical sign
Branch of math meaning "pebble" in Latin, it's also related to a word that means "to determine by math"
1959 grand prize winner at Cannes, it set the legend of Orpheus & Eurydice during carnival in Rio
Mel Gibson hit the road again in this 1st sequel to George Miller's "Mad Max"
Lina Wertmuller film in which Giancarlo Giannini plays a small-time hood with 7 ugly sisters
Originally a Swedish miniseries, this Ingmar Bergman film was called "Scener ur ett aktenskap"
"Knife in the Water", Roman Polanski's 1st feature film, was made in this language
Any ability or accomplishment that makes a person suitable for a particular position or task
Vaduz is the capital of this 62 square mile principality nestled between Switzerland & Austria
To be of a contemplative form of mind, like Hume or Whitehead
The Book of Common Prayer says the peace of God "passeth all" of this
The loss of water vapor from the surface of a plant, usually through open stomata

rounds.text: This term for a small, out-of-the-way town is also the name of a long-gone Algonquian Indian tribe
